metadata.story_name:
*Peace must not prevail.*

War is brewing to the south, an ancient territorial dispute rekindled with surprising and deadly fervour.

*The blood price must be paid.*

Bandits plague the roads of the borderlands, pushing up towards the sinister marshland known as the Birchmere.  The very swamp where, if the legends speak true, an artefact of unimaginable evil was lost centuries ago, and has languished ever since.

*Take up the sword and conquer.*

The Sword of Souls awaits its hour to corrupt another foolish victim - and through its agent bathe the whole continent in blood.

*Listen to my song... and be lost.*

In Eastholt, over a hundred miles north of the Birchmere, a weapon master's daughter has gone missing.  All signs point to her having run away in search of a legendary weapon, wanting to become a mighty hero and save her country the pain of yet another war.

Could it be the Sword of Souls that she seeks in her ignorance?  Either way, her father is determined to put a stop to her plans before she or anyone else can get hurt.  He recruits a search party to find his wayward Lydia and bring her back home...

[Setting Notes can be found here: http://tinyurl.com/ko6y37t]

writing_prompt: A worried weapons master hires you and a group of adventurers to track down his headstrong daughter, who has run away to find a legendary sword that could either save the realm or doom it entirely.

metadata.story_name:
Few are immune to the lure of a fabled lost treasure.  You certainly aren't.

Maybe treasure-hunting was your first choice for a way of life.  Maybe you're just in dire need of some fast coin.  Whatever the reason, you're part of a small band of adventurers on the trail of the near-mythical ruby known as the Heart of Fire, one of the most famous treasures from the days of the Old Princes of Ishkarin.

Certainly the most famous to have never been found.

The jewel alone, with its reputed size and powers--not to mention its historical value--could set you all up for life.  With the rest of the rumoured missing hoard... well, rich beyond your wildest dreams is such a subjective statement, isn't it?

It won't be easy, of course.  There has to be a reason *why* the Heart has remained unclaimed for so many years, when your group is hardly the first to seek it.  The Lost City, where the gem is thought to be, seems determined to live up to its name.

But then, as they say in the Temple of Naukar: *Everything now found was once lost.*

writing_prompt: A band of treasure hunters arrives in a desert town, claiming to have a map to the fabled Lost City—a place shrouded in mystery, greed, and divine curses. But as whispers of their quest spread, the locals wonder: are they brave, foolish, or something far more dangerous?

metadata.story_name:
One of the first rules for understanding humans is that no matter how wondrous anything may be, it *will* become commonplace and beset by petty complaints.

And so it was with interstellar travel.

Once nothing but a dream woven by scientifically-minded fantasists, warp propulsion brought it into the world of the possible.  At first only for the very rich, attended by every luxury... but as the days of Stephenson's Rocket and The Flying Scotsman gave way to Southern Rail, so too did space travel fall into the hands of the masses.

What had been unthinkable was now just another mode of transport.  People griped about delays and wrote lifestyle articles about coping with "warp boredom".  

It only got worse as the New Age of Colonisation made long voyages more common.  Setting up a new life on another world, under a sun that no human had ever seen was daunting enough, but coping with a month or more in deep space?

It was no wonder that long-haul space-travel became seen as "dangerous".  Oh, not *physically* dangerous, or at least no more so than the aeroplanes of bygone centuries.  No, this was more of a social danger, as there were whispers of colonies imploding through interpersonal drama before anyone even touched the ground.

Probably exaggerated, of course, but unsettling nonetheless...

writing_prompt: You’ve just boarded the *Symphonia*, a low-budget colony ship promising adventure and a fresh start among the stars. But as you settle into your cramped cabin and meet your mysterious bunkmate, it becomes clear that not everything—or everyone—onboard is as it seems. What secrets does this journey hold?
